ğŸ” TCP vs. UDP

âš¡ UDP (User Datagram Protocol) â€“ "Connectionless"

No handshakes, no guarantees. Faster, but no error checking or re-sending. Used when speed > reliability.

Examples:
DHCP â€“ Assigns IP addresses fast
TFTP â€“ Simple file transfers where errors donâ€™t matter much

ğŸ§  Exam Tip: UDP = Send it and forget it

ğŸ”— TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) â€“ "Connection-oriented"

Establishes a connection first (3-way handshake). Reliable, guaranteed delivery. Resends lost packets, ensures order.

Examples:
HTTPS â€“ Secure web browsing
SSH â€“ Secure remote shell sessions

ğŸ§  Exam Tip: TCP = Slow but safe
